title-group.article-title: Simulation of the yarn transportation dynamics in a warp knitting machine

article-meta.aff: 1Federal Institute for Materials Research and Testing; Department 5: Materials Engineering; Division 3 Mechanical Behaviour of Polymers; Working Group: Fatigue Testing, Failure Analysis, Damage Mechanics, formerly Institute of Solid Mechanics, Technische Universität Dresden, Germany
2Faculty of Mechanical Science and Engineering, Institute of Solid Mechanics, Technische Universität Dresden, Germany
3Faculty of Mechanical Science and Engineering, Institute of Textile Machinery and High Performance Material Technology, Technische Universität Dresden, Germany

author-notes.corresp: Gerald Hoffmann, Faculty of Mechanical Science and Engineering, Technische Universität Dresden, 01062 Dresden, Germany. Email: gerald.hoffmann@tu-dresden.de

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: To date, in the textile manufacturing process of warp knitting, trouble-shooting and process optimization mainly rely on empirical knowledge and experiments. This factor limits the achievable increase in productivity and quality. On the other hand, using simulations, different phenomena that affect the quality of the knitted fabric and the knitting process can be clarified in the run-up of the experiments. Consequently, an increase in quality and flexibility can be reached with reduced experimental effort. This paper presents a process simulation of the warp thread dynamics in the thread feeding system of a warp knitting machine. For this purpose, a continuum model of the warp thread that includes the spatial dynamics of the thread and the axial transport movement has been developed.

body.p: The textile and clothing industry in Western Europe is going through a restructuring phase, in order to be able to compete in a global market. To ensure competitiveness despite higher salary and production costs, process optimization and thereby a decrease in production costs has to be achieved through continuous research and development. One important instrument to raise efficiency is the simulation of yarn transportation. This paper presents a yarn transport simulation using the example of a warp knitting machine.

Up to now, in the textile manufacturing process of warp knitting, the mechanical and technological influences have been tuned according to empirical knowledge and experiments. This requires a great effort in time, material and labor. The influence of constructional or technological modifications on the yarn transportation can only be identified by in situ tests. Numerical simulations of yarn dynamics in the area of yarn transportation, used in weaving and knitting, offer an estimation of warp tension and other process parameters resulting in an optimized process with reduced experimental effort.

Up to the present, there are no sophisticated simulations for warp knitting. However, the high flexibility and variety of products and the economical relevancy of warp knitting make the application of numerical simulations highly desirable for process optimization. Aims of the simulations are the reduction of set-up times and experiments, an increase of the product quality and an increase of the flexibility of the method concerning strain sensitive and thin threads. Furthermore, the calculation of maximum permitted speed and the optimization of trajectories of the machine parts would allow for a further increase in machine speed.

The existing simulations from weaving and knitting treat the thread as massless and omit lateral dynamics. However, at high machining speed and fineness of the thread in a warp knitting machine, the lateral dynamics do matter. Regarding this fact, the presented model includes the description of yarn as a one-dimensional transported continuum with a mass assignment incorporating its spatial dynamics.
There already are some approaches to simulate process parameters in practical use today.

In the dissertation of De Weldige,1 published in 1996, a model to simulate the warp tension in weaving processes was described. The thread was assumed as a linear elastic, massless and flexible spring element. The friction between the thread and solid bodies was neglected. An additional dissertation concerning this topic was published in 1998 by Chen.2 The assumptions concerning the thread were the same as in the previous work.1 In 2000, Beitelschmidt3 presented a more sophisticated model for the weaving process that included woven fabric in addition to the warp. In this model, a multi-body simulation was employed, which also described the drive technology and cybernetics of the weaving machine. Analogous to a flow model, the thread was specified by its mass assignment as the state variable. Distinct features of this model were the consideration of friction between the thread and solid bodies and its parametric design. Großmann et al.4 developed a simulation model of the weaving process and implemented it into Matlab Simulink. The model allowed for transient computation of dynamic interactions between the weaving machine and the fabric take-down system in the warp direction. The components of the weaving machine were represented by mass inertia and imposed loads. The unsupported thread segments were modeled as non-linear spring-damper elements. Further publications dealing with the simulation of the mechanical behavior of the thread in looms are, for instance, Vangheluwe et al.,5 Ullrich6 and De Meulemeester et al.7

In the dissertation of Ünal8 in 2003 the thread tensioning element of a warp knitting machine was analyzed, simulated and optimized. The movement of the leaf spring compensator was described by trigonometric functions and was integrated in a simulation of the warp knitting process. The thread is assumed to be a linear, scalar spring.

For the knitting process, a model to simulate the thread strain in high-speed circular knitting machines was developed.8–10 A defining feature of this model was the examination of the static state of the yarn transportation. The thread was described by its stress–strain behavior, and the influences of the mechanical elements of yarn transportation, such as wear points, thread brakes and feeder, were included. The mass of the thread was neglected. A distinctive feature was the modular design enabling the construction of different yarn transportation systems by employing several object libraries. Yin and Gu11 presented the simulation of the ballooning process in the ring spinning machine.

The elementary principle that unifies all the methods of yarn transportation is a transported thread that oscillates due to dynamic excitations. The description of the thread as a one-dimensional continuum is intuitively clear. Methods to abstract the problem of an excited and transported thread to the dynamics of a one-dimensional continuum have been discussed in many publications in the domain of mechanics.

Dresig and Weiß12 gave an overview of thread models concerning problem-specific simulations of the thread dynamics. A practical application of two general thread models describing the thread as a string or a beam was presented in the dissertation of Berger.13 Besides stability analysis, parametrically controlled oscillation was examined. In 2007, Zwiers14 published an extensive examination of the dynamics of axially moving strings discussing cases of inductile, flexible and rigid one-dimensional continua as string and beam models. In addition to the constant transport speed, the accelerated movement with variable pretension, free oscillation and stability problems were discussed.

Other publications in this domain, for example by Li et al.,15 employed this approach for an adaptive oscillation control. Lin and Hu16 detailed methods to decrease and control oscillation of one-dimensional, transported continua by using active dampers based on wave absorption. Wegmann and Pfeiffer17 also presented a simulation of the dynamics of threads. Problems of contact and slide-friction influence on the dynamics of moving continua were elaborated by Hetzler.18 Hung et al.19 deals with the simulation of the yarn–object interaction.

sec.title: Warp knitting and process parameters
sec.p:
Textile surfaces produced by warp knitting are characterized by the formation of loops. Figure 1 depicts the sequences of the warp knitting process by using the concrete example of the high-performance warp knitting machine COPCENTRA 3K by LIBA Maschinenfabrik PLC.20 The methodical orientation and the parametric software design ensure a broad applicability on warp knitting machines. The yarn material is transported from the warp beams by the help of accessory and tensioning elements. Unsupported thread segments are referred to as thread segments. On the knitting location, loops are formed by threads and are released afterwards. Finished textile surfaces are pulled by rollings and then stored. In Figure 1, the blue area highlights the scope of the presented simulation. The adjacent sequences of storing yarn material and assembly are incorporated as boundary conditions. Figure 1.
Sequences of the warp knitting process, using the concrete example of the high-performance warp knitting machine COPCENTRA 3K by LIBA Maschinenfabrik PLC.20 (Color online only.).

The requirement for producing high-quality knit fabric is the constant and low tension of each single thread over the whole working width while transporting the yarn. Tensile peaks and high tensions exceeding the tensile strength can break the thread and cause a decrease of quality and merchantability. A yarn break leads to a machine breakdown that has to be corrected manually and therefore limits economic profit. Flaws in quality are visible stopmarks caused by machine breakdown, optical inhomogeneity and haptics through high variation of the yarn tension. However, too low tensions or slackness result in faulty formation of loops and clamping.

The fundamental problem of the yarn transportation is the discrepancy of the constant speed of yarn delivery from the warp beam and the periodical discontinuous need of yarn caused by the formation of loops. To achieve nearly constant tension, a thread compensation and an oscillation diminishment are necessary.

There are a variety of influences on the dynamics of yarn transportation (shown in Figure 2). In the following, major influences are briefly presented. Figure 2.
Factors influencing the warp knitting process.

Thread-leading elements guide the thread from the warp beam to the knitting point and limit the lengths of unsupported thread segments. The natural frequencies of the thread increase when the free lengths are reduced so that the geometry of the yarn transportation contributes to a low oscillation transport. A surface treatment of the thread-leading elements diminishes friction.

Additional components of the yarn transportation are the yarn combs, which separate the threads, and the tensioning element compensating the periodical discontinuous need of yarn. Experiments show that high machine speed leads to an oscillation stimulation of the leaf spring compensator and therefore causes oscillations of the warp thread.21 This stimulation is induced by the high mass of the compensator resulting in low natural frequencies and low material damping.

The leaf spring compensator shown in Figure 3 is used in the presented model and its dynamics are calculated by a finite element substructure. Figure 3.
Leaf spring compensator. (a) finite-element-model (b) structure and function.

The basic idea of finite element substructuring is the minimization of calculation times reducing the degree of freedom of complex structures to the required master degrees. System matrices representing complete structures are calculated for these master degrees. The system of differential equations describing the damped, forced oscillations of the substructure of the leaf spring compensator is (1)Mq→·· (t )+Bq→· (t )+Cq→ (t )=F→(t), where M is the mass matrix, B is the damping matrix, C is the stiffness matrix, q→(t) is the column matrix of freedom degrees and F→(t) is the column matrix of external loadings.

Inter alia, the processing speed influences the natural frequencies of the yarn transportation model and has to be set depending on the binding and the thread material. The thread material is described by its stress–strain behavior ascertained in tension tests, its mass and mass density, the geometry of its cross-section and the damping behavior. An approximate damping constant of the system’s first mode, employed for modal damping, is identified by decay tests. It is assumed that the thread material is linear elastic. The initial load of the threads is tuned according to the binding and the material. Optical and haptic characteristics of the knitted fabric are defined by the yarn material, the binding and the count of needles per unit of length. The binding indicates how the stitch wales are connected and determines the flexibility and drapability, as well as optical and haptic characteristics. In addition, the binding defines the spatial dynamic displacement excitation of the thread at the knitting point. These periodical functions are incorporated in the model as displacement excitations that are approximated by the first terms of their Fourier series.

sec.title: Mathematic modeling
sec.p: The basic attribute of a thread is its very small dimension of cross-section compared to its length, resulting in the mechanical description as a one-dimensional continuum. Mass and material properties, as well as kinematic and kinetic parameters, are assigned to the coordinate of the longitudinal direction of the thread. In the remaining directions the expansions are included by cross-section data.

An estimation of a model using non-dimensional parameters was presented by Weiss.22 On this foundation, the spatial dynamic of a mass-assigned strain proof thread is modeled excluding bending and torsional rigidity. The derivation of the differential equations of the string and the strain bar is based on the second-order theory, which balances the equilibrium of the deformed element. Assuming small deformations compared to the thread length, the first-order theory is applied and, consequently, decoupled linear partial equations for the three spatial directions of oscillations are obtained. Furthermore, the material behavior in the relevant strain interval is linear elastic. Based on this foundation, the partial differential equations of an axially moving string are derived.

Detailed derivations of the wave equation are presented by Hagedorn,23 Wauer,24 Kauderer,25 Nayfeh and Pai26 and Wittenburg.27 The dynamics of moving one-dimensional continua are described by Berger,13 Zwiers,14 Li et al.,15 Metzkes,21 Wauer,24 Lengoc and McCallion,28 Kim and Lee29 and Wickert and Mote.30

sec.title: Partial differential equations
sec.p: The derivation of the partial differential equations describing the spatial dynamic of the thread is based on Hamilton’s principle, which can be depicted as follows: of all possible trajectories starting in xa and ending in xe, only one for which the action ∏ is stationary and its first variation δ∏ is zero is traversed naturally.

The action is described by the integral of the Lagrangian L over time. In classical mechanics of conservative systems with holonomic constraints, the Lagrangian is the difference between kinetic energy T and strain energy Uges=U-Ua: (2)L=T-U+Ua.
The kinetic energy T is as follows: (3)T=∫0 L12ρ0A0 (u,t 2+u,t 2+u,t 2 )dx.

The potential energy U of an oscillating stationary thread is (4 \rm a)U=∫0 L∫A012Exɛx 2dA 0dx.
(4\rm b)U=12Ex [∫0 LA0 (u,x+12 (u,x 2+u,x 2 ) )2 + Iyyu,xx 2+Izzu,xx 2dx ].

The potential of external loads of a line load in the y-direction fy (x,t ) is (5)Ua=∫0 Lfy (x,t )uydx. where ui(x,t)(i=x,y,z) are the spatial displacements, ρ0A0 is the mass assignment of the thread, Ex the Young’s-modulus, ɛx the axial strain and N0 the pretension of the thread (Figure 4). Figure 4.
Model of an axially moving thread.
A transformation (Equation (6)) from global (x,y,z) to local coordinates (X,y,z) is used to incorporate the constant moving speed cs of the thread: (6)x=cst+X.
The global coordinate x is transformed to a function of the local coordinate X and the time t. Thus, the functions of displacement become (7)ui (x,t )=ui (x (X,t ),t )i=x,y,z.

Therefore, the partial derivative with respect to time u,t becomes the total differential u·i. The kinetic energy of the moving thread (Equation (3)) is adapted accordingly: (8)T=12ρ0A0∫0 L (cs 2+∑i=x,y,zu·i 2 )dx.

u·i is evaluated according to the material derivation with respect to time: (9)u·i=duidt=∂ui∂t+∂ui∂xdxdt=u,t+csu,x. With regard to the following assumptions about small displacements, the Kirchhoff–Love theory and the thread limpness, the first variation of action (10)δΠ=δ∫tL (u,t,u,t,u,t,u,x,u,x,u,x,u,xx, u,xx,uy )dt=0 leads to the partial differential equations describing the dynamics of an axially moving thread: (11a)u,tt+2csu,tx+ (cs 2-cL 2 )u,xx=0
(11b)u,tt+2csu,tx+ (cs 2-cQ 2 )u,xx=fy(x,t)ρ0A0
(11c)u,tt+2csu,tx+ (cs 2-cQ 2 )u,xx=0 where cL and cQ are the wave propagation speeds of the longitudinal transverse oscillation: (12a)cL=Exρ0
(12b)cQ=N0ρ0A0 These equations are valid for the subsonic range |cs |< |ci | with i=L,Q. Distributed and concentrated loads are considered analogously.

sec.title: Discretization
sec.p: The presented partial differential equations describing the thread dynamics as a continuous problem are discretized by applying the Ritz method. The following ordinary differential equations are obtained: (13)Mq··(t)+Gq· (t )+Cq (t )=F→RB (t )+F→ (t ).

In contrast to the finite elements method (FEM), n shape functions are chosen for an interval and the approximate solutions are the sum of n interfering approximate solutions. By using the FEM, the interval is divided into geometric, primitive finite elements for which shape functions are selected.

Approximate solutions are calculated for each element by taking the consistency requirements at the element borders into account. A detailed presentation of the validation of the FEM-model can be found in Metzkes.21

The general form of the Ritz approach for displacement functions of one-dimensional continua: (14a)u→i (x,t )= (u~RBi (x,t )+∑k=1 KiUik (xi )pik (t ) )e→i
(14b)= (u~RBi (x,t )+U→i T(x)q→i (t ) )e→i withi=x,y,z

fulfills inhomogeneous geometric boundary conditions by u~RBi(x,t). The quasi-static state is described if linear functions are chosen as shape functions: (15)u~RBi (x,t )=u~RBai (x,t )+u~RBei (x,t )=pai (t )Ua (x )+pei (t )Ue (x )

Usually, trigonometric or polynomial functions, which depend on the location and fulfill the homogeneous boundary conditions, are selected as shape functions Uik(x). The time-dependent functions pik(t) are the degrees of freedom of the discretized system.

If the time-dependent functions of the inhomogeneous, geometric boundary conditions are known, the column matrix of load excitation is directly calculated from these, while all other chosen shape functions form the system matrices. If these boundary (pai (t ) and pei(t)) conditions are not identified, all shape functions are assumed to form the system matrices.
For modeling the spatial dynamics of thread segments, the Ritz shape functions are combined to obtain the corresponding system matrices.
The column matrix structure of the degrees of freedom with respect to time defines the structure of the system matrices: (16)q→F T (t )= [q→x T (t )|q→y T (t )|q→z T (t )|q→RB T (t ) ].

The differential equations describing the transverse oscillation are formally identical and are therefore combined: (17)u→yz=u→y (x,t )+u→z (x,t )= [ (0→T |0→T |0→T|0 0 0 0 0 0 )e→x (0→T |U→y T |0→T|0 0UaUe0 0 )e→y (0→T |0→T |Uz T|0 0 0 0UaUe )e→z ]q→F (t )= [ (0→T )e→x (U→Fy T )e→y (U→Fz T )e→z ]q→F (t )=Ω→Fyz (x )q→F (t ).

This approach considers the thread as a continuum visualized by the distorted oscillation around the longitudinal axis. Analogous to the transverse, the longitudinal oscillation is given by (18)u→x (x,t )= [ (U→x T |0→T |0→T|UaUe0 0 0 0 )e→x (0→T |0→T |0→T|0 0 0 0 0 0 )e→y (0→T |0→T |0→T|0 0 0 0 0 0 )e→z ]q→F (t )= [ (U→Fx T )e→x (0→T )e→y (0→T )e→z ]q→Fi (t )=Ω→Fx (x )q→F (t ).

The discretization is applied by substituting the displacement functions and their derivatives in Equations (4b), (5) and (8) with the Ritz shape functions (Equations (17) and (18)). The system matrices are obtained by computing the first variation of the principle function of Hamilton: (19)δΠ=δ∫tL (q→F (t ),q→ (t ),t· ).
Mass matrix: (20)MF=ρ0A0∫0 L (Ω→Fyz (x )Ω→Fyz T (x )+Ω→Fx (x )Ω→Fx T (x ) )dx.
Gyroscopic matrix: (21)GF=2ρ0A0cs∫0 L (Ω→Fyz (x )ΩFyz 'T (x )+Ω→Fx (x )Ω→Fx 'T (x ) )dx.

Stiffness matrix: (22)CF=(-ρ0A0cs 2+N0)∫0 L (Ω→Fyz ' (x )Ω→Fyz 'T (x ) )dx +(-ρ0A0cs 2+ExA0)∫0 L (Ω→Fx ' (x )ΩFx 'T (x ) )dx. The column matrices of excitation, occurring because of inhomogeneous geometric boundary conditions and external loads, are computed according to this principle.21 The damping matrix is incorporated by modal damping. The spatial dynamic of an axially moving thread is given by (23)MFq→··F (t )+GFq→F · (t )+CFq→F (t )=F→RB (t ).

sec.title: Model of thread transportation
sec.p:
Based on the system matrices of a thread segment, the complete model describing the thread transportation dynamics in the warp knitting machine COPCENTRA 3K is developed. Figure 5 illustrates the model comprising three thread segments, one leading element and the leaf spring compensator. The individual elements are coupled by boundary and transmission conditions, and the excitation results from the spatial displacement excitation at the knitting point. Figure 5.
Model of the thread transportation in warp knitting machines.

The column matrix of the degrees of freedom with respect to time: (24)q→ges T= [q→F1 T (t )q→F2 T (t )q→C T (t )q→F3 T(t) ] comprises the degrees of freedom with respect to time of the thread sequences q→Fj (t ) (j=1,2,3 ) and of the leaf spring compensator. Figure 6 shows the corresponding assignment of the system matrices. Figure 6.
Assignment of the system matrices of a thread sequence (left) and the complete system (right); K refers to the number of shape functions and C indicates the compensator.

A reduction of the system matrices (Figure 6, right) is achieved by the application of boundary and transition conditions that couple the thread segments and the compensator. This results in a thread transportation model with reduced system matrices and the column matrix of load excitation, which simply consists of the excitations at the knitting point (Figure 7). Figure 7.
Assignment of the system matrices of the complete system (a) and the column matrix of the excitation (b).

sec.title: Boundary and transmission conditions
sec.p: The excitation of the thread is given by the spatial movement at the knitting point, which leads to the loop formation. These periodic functions are incorporated by the first elements of their Fourier series.

To describe the transmission condition at the compensator, the following assumptions are made.
Applying first-order theory, small displacements and time-independent basis vectors are assumed.
The contact between the thread and the leaf spring compensator is reduced to a point. Therefore, there is no moment acting at this point. Hence, the system matrices describing the dynamics of the compensator are reduced to displacement degrees of freedom.
The displacement of the thread in the global y-direction is suppressed by the comb.
A continuous contact point between the thread and the compensator is assumed.

sec.title: Friction
sec.p: The kinetic friction between the thread and the compensator is described by the Euler–Eytelwein equation. Hence, the direction of the frictional force depends on the relative velocity between both friction partners and is assumed by a signed friction coefficient μC. The growth of the longitudinal force due to friction is given by (25)ΔFC (t )=FRB2x (eμC (t )αC-1 ).

The rotating support of the leading element causes the longitudinal force to be influenced by bearing friction (Figure 8). Neglecting the contact, and hence the slip between the threads and the leading element, the friction force is described by (26)ΔF=μ2didasin (α/2 )FRB1x, where FRB2x and FRB1x are longitudinal forces resulting from inhomogeneous, geometric boundary conditions and forces. Fractions of longitudinal force caused by oscillation are neglected in the description of friction. The reduction is applied by the presented boundary and transmission conditions and leads to the following time-dependent column matrix of degrees of freedom: (27)q→T (t )= [q→x1 Tq→y1 Tq→z1 T |q→x2 Tq→y2 Tq→z2 T |pa2y |q→x3 Tq→y3 Tq→z3 T |pa3xpa3z ], where the time-dependent functions pa3x(t) and pa3z(t) describe the movement of a thread in the third segment at the compensator. It is at this point that the dynamic coupling between the thread and the compensator develops. In Figure 7, the assignments of the system matrices and the column matrix of load excitation are depicted for the reduced system. Equation (28) describes the dynamic of the excited axially moving thread in the feeding system of a warp knitting machine: (28)Mq→·· (t )+Gq→· (t )+Cq→ (t )=F→ (t ).
Figure 8.
Longitudinal force caused by bearing friction.

sec.title: Solution
sec.p: The presented dynamic model is excited by periodical displacement functions. Hence, the solution is found in the frequency range by calculating the time response and neglecting transient effects. The solution includes frequency-dependent amplitudes and phase shifts of model quantities, such as displacements and loads, as well as frequency and phase responses. Furthermore, a modal analysis calculating natural frequencies and natural modes of the thread transportation model is accomplished.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: To verify the presented numerical model, its solutions are compared to the results of experiments performed on the warp knitting machine COPCENTRA 3K. All the experiments concerning the movement of the compensator, thread tension and model parameters have been executed at the Institute of Textile Machinery and High Performance Material Technology at the Technische Universität Dresden. For the amplitude measurement of the leaf spring compensator movement, laser triangulation was applied. The longitudinal force of the thread was measured with a thread tension sensor that has a relative error of 10% caused by friction and power-on drift.

sec.title: Solutions in frequency range
sec.p:
In Figures 9 and 10, the results of the measurements and simulations of the movement of the leaf spring compensator and the thread tension are compared. Figure 9 shows that the simulation model approximates the amplitude of the leaf spring compensator. Figure 10, however, depicts a major deviation between measurement and calculation of the thread tension. The measured maximum thread tension is about 22% higher than the equivalent value of the simulation. This is due to the following reasons: whereas the movement of the leaf spring compensator was measured as a function of time in the experiments, the results of the calculation are based on harmonic analyzes, which reflect the quasi-static, steady state. The results of the harmonic analysis are averages of non-linear variables. For the thread tension measurement, the relative error of 10% for the longitudinal force has to be considered.31,32 Furthermore, a constant thread pretension is assumed in the simulation, while in reality this holds only approximately true. In addition, the simulation uses ideal excitation functions measured at very low line speed. Disturbances of the excitation functions at higher line speed caused by mechanical clearance or other phenomena of actuator dynamics are not incorporated into the simulation but measured in the experiments. Such disturbances would cause the excitation of higher Fourier orders. The simulation only incorporates the movement of the guide bar as the excitation function and not the whole process of loop formation. Hence, the transient excitation of the system caused by the contact of the compound needle is not taken into account. Singularities such as possible flaws of the warp thread material or snarl of the warp thread are also neglected. Figure 9.
Movement of the leaf spring compensator (input angular frequency 1000 rpm).
Figure 10.
Longitudinal force of the thread (input angular frequency 1000 rpm).

sec.title: Analysis of the natural frequencies
sec.p:
Figure 11 depicts the system’s natural frequencies as a function of the relative stiffness of the leaf spring compensator. A more elastic leaf spring compensator results in a major decrease of the system’s natural frequencies. With the help of such evaluations excitations, near-natural frequencies can be identified. This information can be used to modify and optimize the machine. Figures 12(a) and (b) show the influence of the transport speed and the mass assignment of the thread on the natural frequencies. Figure 11.
The system’s natural frequencies as functions of the relative stiffness of the leaf spring compensator.
Figure 12.
The system’s natural frequencies as functions of the quotient of transportation speed and the wave propagation speed (a) and the system’s natural frequencies as functions of the yarn fineness (b).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Existing simulations of yarn transportation treat the thread as massless and omit lateral dynamics. Experiments show that at high machining speed and high thread fineness, the lateral dynamics influence the process. Therefore, a continuous mechanical description of the warp thread is presented using the string or, respectively, the strain bar theory. The one-dimensional continuum is assumed to be mass assigned, strain proof, and not rigid against bending and torsion. The material behavior is characterized as linear elastic. In addition to the spatial oscillation, the constant transport speed of the thread is included. The corresponding partial differential equations are discretized by applying the global Ritz approach. In the model, the thread segments are coupled by boundary and transition conditions given by the characteristics of the system, including bearing and kinetic friction. The leaf spring compensator is incorporated as a FEM substructure. The solutions are therefore calculated in the frequency range, representing the steady state of the model. To validate the model, the intrinsically transient response is examined and several parametric case studies are performed. A first experimental verification shows that the model is able to simulate the thread in the feeding system. It is shown that the whole warp knitting machine influences the thread transportation. Therefore, further research should concentrate on incorporation of the influence of machine drive and aspects of control engineering. Furthermore, impact loads of the thread demand a transient solution that simulates the transient effect. An extension of the model for non-linear elastic thread materials and different compensators is essential for further research. To represent the whole warp knitting process, including loop formation, a thread model incorporating bending stiffness has to be chosen.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
